title: Tutorial should now replace Ryze with a simpler mage.
body:
After Ryze rework, the tutorial still uses Ryze as an example of a mage. This is not good for a number of reasons.

Ryze doesn't use a generic mage build. Ryze scales from maximum mana (although less than before rework, he still benefits a lot from mana), and this means that playing Ryze will be different from playing a more generic mage.

Ryze passive is difficult to understand for beginners.
> Ryze's spells grants a stack of Arcane Mastery for 12 seconds, stacking up to 5 times.
At 5 stacks, Ryze becomes supercharged for 3 + (1 per Desperate Power's rank) seconds, gaining a shield that blocks「 20 + (5 × Ryze's level) 」(+ 8% of his max. mana) damage
While Arcane Mastery's shield holds, Ryze's spellcasts reduce his other spells' cooldowns by「 Overload's cooldown 」, able to be brought to a minimum of 0.25 seconds.

Compared to Ashe (although the reworked passive may be a bit confusing) and Garen, the other two options. This is problematic because the game pauses at one time to tell you to look at the passive.


I suggest switching out Ryze with simpler mages like {{champion:1}} (only difficult mechanic is controlling tibbers), {{champion:30}} (easy to understand passive, and lack of skillshots that can be blocked), {{champion:55}} (simple mechanics), or {{champion:99}} (simple mechanics and passive).
I'm saying that these champions are easy to learn, not necessarily easy to master. I hope I didn't insult anyone who mains these champions.

I feel like this would be more beginner friendly.
The tutorial itself feels a little intrusive (every time I tried to towerdive someone, the tutorial stopped me), and it needs to be changed overall. But until then, small changes to make it more beginner-friendly, please?

Why do skillshots matter? These are people learning league it isn't like they are missing an eye, and 4 fingers. They know how to land abilities if they have played any other game.

Landing bullets in fps is different from landing skillshots on league.
I also played starcraft and warcraft 3 before starting league, and since those games are more focused on strategy than micromanagement (although it is pretty heavy on micromanagement) pretty much all the skillshots are ground targeted. Practicing skillshots is important.

But even still playing games in general heightens your reflexes, things like skillshots shouldn't or normally wouldn't phase anyone. "Oh I have to aim and hit them" isn't a lost concept a newbie couldn't understand, Point and click can be easier to land, but not choosing a tutorial mage because of skillshots is incredibly short sighted.

I also argue that shooting people in a shooter is similar given you are aiming and shooting in both, not in the same manner, but I think players at this point understand what leading a target is, and aiming. We can't assume everyone new to the game has never played a video game before.
The main thing about having minimal skillshots is that if they miss shots, they're gonna be discouraged, and new players are already heavily discouraged as-is.

I don't know about you or anyone else but when I start a game anew, I don't go in thinking I will be good at it right away. Lux is straight forward, just because her abilities take some minor aiming doesn't mean they are going to discourage users, if everyone operated that way well the community wouldn't be as massive as it is currently.
Considering everything in league will be a skillshot at this pace, we should probably have that in the tutorial.
